title: Big banks so far have moved just 1,000 jobs out of U.K. before Brexit, survey finds
text:
Getty Images A rainbow appears over the financial district of Canary Wharf in east London.

For all of the complaints from major banks about the potential disruption from Brexit, fewer than 1,000 positions have been moved out of the U.K. to Europe, according to a survey released Thursday.

The report, from accounting giant EY, said that more jobs could yet go. The figure represents just 15% of the investment banking staff currently marked for relocation to Europe, the accountancy said.

EY, which based its report on the public statements of 222 firms, said the value of assets which could move out of the U.K. as a result of Brexit was around £1 trillion.

“Financial services firms have the building blocks in place, but have so far transferred fewer staff and assets to the continent than expected,” said Omar Ali, U.K. financial services leader at EY, in a statement.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson has said that he wants to withdraw the U.K. from the European Union on Oct. 31. A previous deadline of March forced the sector to be prepared for an earlier exit.

EY said 21% of financial services companies have spoken about their concerns about the economic impact of Brexit, noting the negative effect it is having or will have on their business, including reduced profitability, deferred M&A, slowdown in lending and customer losses.
description: For all of the complaints from major banks about the potential disruption from Brexit, fewer than 1,000 positions have been moved out of the U.K. to Europe,...
